title: Old-Time Sayings
description: Complete these classic old-time proverbs and sayings!

questions.proverb: Don't count your chickens before they ___
questions.explanation: This means don't assume a positive outcome before it actually happens.

questions.proverb: A bird in the hand is worth two in the ___
questions.explanation: It's better to hold onto what you have than to risk it for something uncertain.
Those who act promptly and get an early start have an advantage.

questions.proverb: You can't teach an old dog new ___
questions.explanation: It can be difficult to change someone's established habits or ways of thinking.
Even in difficult situations, there is usually something positive to be found.

questions.proverb: A penny saved is a penny ___
questions.explanation: Money that you save is just as valuable as money that you earn through work.
What you do matters more than what you say.

questions.proverb: Don't put all your eggs in one ___
questions.explanation: Don't risk everything on a single venture â€” diversify your efforts.

questions.proverb: When in Rome, do as the Romans ___
questions.explanation: When visiting a new place, follow the customs and behavior of the locals.

questions.proverb: The grass is always greener on the other ___
questions.explanation: People tend to think others have it better than they do.
Responding to a wrongdoing with another wrongdoing is not justified.
If you're in need, you should accept what is offered without being picky.

questions.proverb: Don't judge a book by its ___
questions.explanation: Don't form opinions based on outward appearances alone.

questions.proverb: An apple a day keeps the doctor ___
questions.explanation: Eating healthy food helps you stay well and avoid illness.
It's better to do something after the expected time than not to do it at all.
